eurCurrent.note: Critically reduced, dependent on intervention success

casingProgram.details: TOC @ Seabed (205m MD, verified by returns)
TOC @ 2,700m MD. SEVERE CASING DEFORMATION CONFIRMED AT ~4,500m MD (post-2016 intervention)

tubing.integrityNotes: Potential FOD damage and jarring forces from 2016 event

scssv.notes: Likely damaged during 2016 event or blocked by debris

packer.notes: Original 2012 packer. Integrity uncertain due to downhole forces during 2016 event

perforations.status: Inflow potentially restricted by formation damage from uncontrolled pressure cycles

performancePeriods.notes: Declining trend, increasing water cut post-2016 workover

interventions.objective: Run completion string, set packer, test SSSV
Initial well un-plugging and first flow
interventions.lessonsLearned: A promising new producer. Well flowed above prognosis.

interventions.objective: Isolate lower zone due to water cut. Set a retrievable bridge plug @ 4,800m.
interventions.lessonsLearned: A complete procedural and technical failure. The 'Perfect Storm' begins. Root cause: FOD (tong die) led to cascading failures.

subOperations.description: Pull 4.562" QXT lock with BPV equalizing prong (Run 1)
Pull 4.562" QXT lock with BPV equalizing prong (Run 2)

subOperations.notes: Plug element was stuck. After 4 hours of working pipe, the element came free.

subOperations.description: POOH with retrieved plug assembly - CRITICAL FAILURE
subOperations.notes: Expanded element got stuck on the TRSSV protection sleeve. The sleeve was pulled with the element. Pieces of the element are now missing downhole.

subOperations.description: Fish missing pieces of the plug element
subOperations.notes: Most effective tool was a Junk Basket (JD) with no internal dogs or moving parts. Standard fishing tools were ineffective.
A Camco equalising prong (from the original QXT assembly) was retrieved. Confirmed multiple FOD sources.

subOperations.description: Latch and retrieve the main bridge plug body
subOperations.notes: Inability to latch the external fishing neck. Tools used: overshots, LIBs, blind boxes, bailers, grabs.
LIB retrieved a clear impression of a tong die, but this was not recognized by the on-site team.
subOperations.lessonsLearned: CRITICAL MISSED OPPORTUNITY. The root cause was present but not identified. LIB should have been sent to shore for expert review.

subOperations.description: Final attempt to latch plug body
subOperations.notes: Latched using JD on dummy rope socket with dogs engaged, but had no shear facility. Standard pins sheared repeatedly. Switched to case-hardened steel pins.

subOperations.description: Retrieve plug body after successful latching - THE REVEAL
subOperations.notes: Fish was retrieved. A tong die was wedged in the expander mandrel's internals, preventing the latching tool from fully engaging and causing premature shearing.
subOperations.rootCause: Foreign Object Debris (FOD) - 3/4" tong die from surface operations

interventions.objective: Replace damaged upper completion, assess well integrity
interventions.lessonsLearned: Damaged upper completion was replaced. Multi-finger caliper log revealed severe (>20% ovality) deformation in the 9-5/8" production casing at ~4,500m MD, likely from jarring forces. The well was saved, but it was permanently damaged - now a 'limper'.
The TRSSV was found to be stuck in the closed position, likely due to damage from the 2016 event or debris. The final critical barrier failed. The well's productive life was over.

snapshots.context: Pre-intervention and during bridge plug pull

readings.notes: Slight pressure build, rate drop - jarring initiated
Ann A spike 95→145 psi - significant downhole shock

anomalies.significance: Indicates significant downhole shock event, likely contributing to casing deformation

personnel.name: J. Anderson
personnel.performance: Highly experienced, no major incidents on record

personnel.name: M. Chen
personnel.performance: First time as lead engineer on a subsea HPHT completion. Relied heavily on contractor procedures.

personnel.name: R. Jones
personnel.performance: Meticulous in his daily logs, first to notice subtle production anomalies before the 2016 intervention.
CRITICAL: Crew was on their 14th consecutive night shift. Performance review noted 'fatigue and communication breakdown'. Two junior hands were on the floor during the tong die incident.
Brought in to clean up the 2016 disaster. Operated with extreme caution, but his report noted the 'well is permanently scarred'.

personnel.name: S. Patel
personnel.performance: Inherited the well in 2020. Her detailed risk assessments and push for a comprehensive intervention plan are the reason this case study exists.

correspondence.subject: Re: Plug Pulling Operations
correspondence.excerpt: Mike, the crew is struggling to get a good latch on the plug. We've been working it for four hours now. The jarring is getting aggressive. I'm concerned about the TRSSV profile. The procedure says to pull, but my gut says we need to stop and run a LIB first. The day-shift guy wants to push on. Advise. -J.
correspondence.significance: Supervisor's instinct was overridden by schedule pressure
correspondence.whatIfScenario: If an LIB had been run at this point, the tong die may have been identified early, potentially saving $6M and 4 weeks NPT

correspondence.title: Post-2016 Incident Report - Executive Summary
correspondence.excerpt: The root cause was identified as Foreign Object Debris (FOD), specifically a 3/4" tong die. While the immediate failure was procedural, a contributing factor was the intense schedule pressure to complete the zone isolation before the end of the fiscal year. The decision to proceed with aggressive jarring without a confirmatory LIB was a direct result of this pressure.
correspondence.significance: Formal acknowledgment of schedule pressure as contributing factor

correspondence.title: Management Meeting Minutes
correspondence.excerpt: Action Item 4.2: Review PlugDown Solutions' performance on Well_666. The cost overrun is approaching $5M with no result. Consider alternative vendors for future complex fishing operations. The budget for the 2017 workover is now under review.
correspondence.significance: Management awareness of escalating costs mid-disaster

preJob2016.consequence: Inability to latch plug, fishing job
preJob2016.mitigation: Visual inspection of all wireline tools before RIH
preJob2016.lessonLearned: Visual inspection was inadequate. Procedural controls failed. FOD was the root cause of the entire disaster.

preJob2016.mitigation: Allow 4-hour 'soak' time. Use certified jarring sequence.
preJob2016.lessonLearned: Jarring forces were far more destructive than anticipated, causing secondary failures (SSV, casing).

preJob2016.mitigation: Use shearing safety joint above pulling tool. Pull at controlled speed.
preJob2016.lessonLearned: The risk was severely underestimated. The expanded element acted as an 'uncontrolled spear', pulling the protection sleeve.

lessonsLearned.lesson: Tong dies must be tethered and inventoried before and after every use
lessonsLearned.recommendedAction: Mandatory tether SOP, tool count verification

lessonsLearned.lesson: 14+ consecutive night shifts correlated with incident
lessonsLearned.recommendedAction: Flag for management review, mandatory fatigue assessment

lessonsLearned.lesson: LIB impression showing foreign object was dismissed by on-site team
lessonsLearned.recommendedAction: Mandatory offsite expert review of all diagnostic results

lessonsLearned.lesson: Fiscal year deadline pressure contributed to decision to continue aggressive jarring
lessonsLearned.recommendedAction: Formal risk review required when commercial pressure conflicts with operational caution

lessonsLearned.lesson: Team did not recognize that pulling through TRSSV profile with expanded element was high-risk
lessonsLearned.triggerCondition: POOH with oversized or expanded equipment through safety valve
lessonsLearned.recommendedAction: Mandatory barrier impact assessment for all retrieval operations

whatIfScenarios.scenario: If the LIB impression had been sent to shore for expert review on Nov 15
whatIfScenarios.outcome: The tong die would have been identified within 24 hours

whatIfScenarios.scenario: If a shearing safety joint had been used above the overshot during the plug pull
whatIfScenarios.outcome: The TRSSV profile would not have been damaged. The well would still be producing.

whatIfScenarios.scenario: If crew rotation had been enforced at 10 days maximum
whatIfScenarios.outcome: Fresher crew may have caught the tong die during pre-job inspection or recognized the LIB impression

economics.economicConclusion: Despite the high risk and cost, the Expected Value remains strongly positive, justifying the complex intervention as a necessary commercial investment.

phases.name: Advanced Diagnostics
phases.description: High-resolution multi-finger caliper and ultrasonic imaging to map deformed casing and assess tubing/SSV profile damage

phases.name: SSV Replacement/Bypass
phases.description: Lock failed TRSSV open, install insert retrievable safety valve (IRSV) in dedicated profile above damaged valve

phases.name: Casing Remediation
phases.description: Deploy expandable steel liner or patch across deformed section to restore structural integrity

phases.name: Production Optimization
phases.description: Clean-out and potential stimulation of reservoir section to restore productivity

futurePlans.mediumTerm: Success of intervention is far from guaranteed. Well_666 will serve as the ultimate cautionary tale.
futurePlans.longTerm: High risk of early abandonment if intervention fails. Abandonment cost significantly higher due to downhole complications.

documents.description: Lead Impression Block showing tong die impression - the missed clue
Multi-finger caliper showing casing deformation at 4,500m
Well Barrier Schematic showing current failed elements
